articles.headline: A Credit Score That Ignores the Innocuous Mistake
articles.snippet: One major credit score company, VantageScore, has decided not to downgrade a score for a collection action, as long as the bill was eventually paid.
articles.abstract: One major credit score company, VantageScore, has decided not to downgrade a score for a collection action, as long as the bill was eventually paid.
articles.lead_paragraph: Megan Barringer had no idea that a medical billing mix-up over a $742 charge for a back evaluation six years ago could end up costing her more than $33,000.

articles.headline: Kodak’s Fuzzy Future
articles.snippet: As part of its bankruptcy, Kodak sold well-known businesses to focus on areas that some say are highly competitive or stagnant.
articles.abstract: As part of its bankruptcy, Kodak sold well-known businesses to focus on areas that some say are highly competitive or stagnant.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Eastman Kodak emerges from bankruptcy this summer or fall, it will be a shadow of the blue-chip corporate giant it once was.

articles.headline: Israel Tightens Border Defense as Syria Erupts
articles.snippet: Errant munitions from Syria’s conflict have landed in the Golan Heights some 30 times. But the concern runs deeper along what was one border Israel didn’t have to worry much about.
articles.abstract: Errant munitions from Syria’s conflict have landed in the Golan Heights some 30 times. But the concern runs deeper along what was one border Israel didn’t have to worry much about.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNT HAZEKA, Israel — Elite infantry and reconnaissance units have been moved into the long-quiet Golan Heights this spring. Bulldozers are making way for new military shelters. And at an Israeli Army outpost on a strategic hilltop here, a Merkava tank sits pointing toward Syria — poised to race up a dirt ramp at a moment’s notice.

articles.headline: JPMorgan Directors Feel Heat in a Vote
articles.snippet: As the bank grapples with regulatory battles, some shareholders are taking public aim at individual directors who hold crucial positions on the bank’s audit and risk committees.
articles.abstract: As the bank grapples with regulatory battles, some shareholders are taking public aim at individual directors who hold crucial positions on the bank’s audit and risk committees.
articles.lead_paragraph: As JPMorgan Chase’s annual meeting nears, much of the tension surrounds a critical vote to split the chairman and chief executive roles — a decision that could strip Jamie Dimon, the bank’s influential leader, of the dual titles he has held since 2006. Behind the scenes, though, another battle is brewing.
articles.byline: By Susanne Craig and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: College Graduates Fare Well in Jobs Market, Even Through Recession
articles.snippet: College graduates are the only group that has more people employed today than when the recession started.
articles.abstract: College graduates are the only group that has more people employed today than when the recession started.
articles.lead_paragraph: Is college worth it? Given the growing price tag and the frequent anecdotes about jobless graduates stuck in their parents’ basements, many have started to question the value of a college degree. But the evidence suggests college graduates have suffered through the recession and lackluster recovery with remarkable resilience.

articles.headline: Path From ‘Social Butterfly’ to Boston Suspect’s Widow
articles.snippet: Friends and relatives of Katherine Russell, the widow of one of the suspects in the Boston bombing, are stunned at the turn her life has taken.
articles.abstract: Friends and relatives of Katherine Russell, the widow of one of the suspects in the Boston bombing, are stunned at the turn her life has taken.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Katherine Russell arrived as a freshman at Suffolk University just over five years ago, she seemed to bond so well with her new roommates in their lively dorm opposite Boston Common that one classmate likened them to sitcom characters. “They reminded me of the show ‘Sex and the City,’ ” he recalled. “Two of them were free-spirited, one was materialistic and Katherine was the social butterfly.”
articles.byline: By Michael Cooper, Serge F. Kovaleski, Richard A. Oppel Jr. and John Eligon

articles.headline: Israel Targeted Iranian Missiles in Syria Attack
articles.snippet: Experts said that Israel was taking a calculated risk that limited strikes, aimed at disrupting the arms pipeline that runs from Iran to Hezbollah, would provoke only a limited response.
articles.abstract: Experts said that Israel was taking a calculated risk that limited strikes, aimed at disrupting the arms pipeline that runs from Iran to Hezbollah, would provoke only a limited response.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A series of powerful explosions rocked the outskirts of Damascus early Sunday morning, which Syrian state television said was the result of Israeli missile attacks on a Syrian military installation.
articles.byline: By Anne Barnard, Michael R. Gordon and Jodi Rudoren

articles.headline: Management, to the Barricades!
articles.snippet: Bylaws amendments have been coming fast and furious as the CommonWealth REIT tries to fend off two big shareholders intent on change.
articles.abstract: Bylaws amendments have been coming fast and furious as the CommonWealth REIT tries to fend off two big shareholders intent on change.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE annals of business history abound with stories of entrenched corporate executives building fortifications to maintain their plush status quo. But recent maneuvers by the board of the CommonWealth real estate investment trust put the company in a class by itself. CommonWealth REIT owns office buildings in and around major metropolitan areas in the United States. Founded in 1986 and based in Newton, Mass., CommonWealth, like many REITs, is not taxed on its income, which it distributes to shareholders. Its hefty payouts — 4.75 percent based on its share price of $21.04 — have made it a favorite among individual investors looking for income.

articles.headline: The Apprentices of a Digital Age
articles.snippet: For a small group of the young, digital elite, Enstitute seeks to challenge the conventional wisdom that top professional jobs always require a bachelor’s degree.
articles.abstract: For a small group of the young, digital elite, Enstitute seeks to challenge the conventional wisdom that top professional jobs always require a bachelor’s degree.
articles.lead_paragraph: JASMINE GAO, who is 19, just wasn’t the classroom type. So instead of languishing in college, she dropped out after her freshman year.

articles.headline: Corporations Find a Friend in the Supreme Court
articles.snippet: A new analysis finds the current Supreme Court to be by far the most pro-business of any since World War II.
articles.abstract: A new analysis finds the current Supreme Court to be by far the most pro-business of any since World War II.
articles.lead_paragraph: NOT long after 10 a.m. on March 27, a restless audience waited for the Supreme Court to hear arguments in the second of two historic cases involving same-sex marriage. First, however, Justice Antonin Scalia attended to another matter. He announced that the court was throwing out an antitrust class action that subscribers brought against Comcast, the nation’s largest cable company.

articles.headline: Latest Product From Tech Firms: An Immigration Bill
articles.snippet: Silicon Valley companies and their executives, who want to hire foreign-born engineers, are waging a sophisticated lobbying campaign in support of an immigration overhaul.
articles.abstract: Silicon Valley companies and their executives, who want to hire foreign-born engineers, are waging a sophisticated lobbying campaign in support of an immigration overhaul.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The television advertisement that hit the airwaves in Florida last month featured the Republican Party’s rising star, Senator Marco Rubio, boasting about his get-tough plan for border security.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Somini Sengupta

articles.headline: Small-Town Mayor’s Millions as Exhibit A on Graft in Spain
articles.snippet: At a time of painful austerity in Spain, corruption charges against figures like the former small-town mayor María Victoria Pinilla are stoking bitter resentment.
articles.abstract: At a time of painful austerity in Spain, corruption charges against figures like the former small-town mayor María Victoria Pinilla are stoking bitter resentment.
articles.lead_paragraph: LA MUELA, Spain — In the good times, the former mayor of this small, wind-swept village of 5,000 in northern Spain was busy building: the olive oil museum, the wind museum, the museum of life. If that were not enough, there was the new bullring, the sports center with 25,000 seats and the zoo with the exotic-bird park.

articles.headline: Off-the-Cuff Obama Line Put U.S. in Bind on Syria
articles.snippet: President Obama surprised aides last year when he called the use of chemical weapons in Syria a “red line,” a move that has complicated the American response to evidence that such arms have been used.
articles.abstract: President Obama surprised aides last year when he called the use of chemical weapons in Syria a “red line,” a move that has complicated the American response to evidence that such arms have been used.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Confronted with evidence that chemical weapons have been used in Syria, President Obama now finds himself in a geopolitical box, his credibility at stake with frustratingly few good options.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker, Mark Landler, David E. Sanger and Anne Barnard

articles.headline: The Dark Side, Carefully Masked
articles.snippet: For Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the surviving suspect in the Boston Marathon bombing, there were oblique signs to those around him that the gulf between the private and the public person was widening.
articles.abstract: For Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the surviving suspect in the Boston Marathon bombing, there were oblique signs to those around him that the gulf between the private and the public person was widening.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — On the day after two bombs exploded near the finish line of the Boston Marathon, Dzhokhar Tsarnaev tapped out an early-afternoon text message to a classmate at the University of Massachusetts at Dartmouth. Want to hang out? he queried. Sure, his friend replied.
articles.byline: By Michael Wines and Ian Lovett

articles.headline: Syria Blames Israel for Fiery Attack in Damascus
articles.snippet: Israel would not confirm that it had carried out the airstrikes, but the four explosions near the Syrian capital demonstrated a firepower more potent than any seen before in the country’s civil war.
articles.abstract: Israel would not confirm that it had carried out the airstrikes, but the four explosions near the Syrian capital demonstrated a firepower more potent than any seen before in the country’s civil war.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Syrian government publicly condemned Israel for a powerful air assault on military targets near Damascus early Sunday, saying it “opened the door to all possibilities,” as fear spread throughout the region that the country’s civil war could expand beyond its borders.

articles.headline: Last Hope in Ruins: Bangladesh’s Race to Save Shaheena
articles.snippet: The story of Shaheena offered the last bit of hope of finding anyone alive in what is now considered the deadliest accident in the history of the garment industry.
articles.abstract: The story of Shaheena offered the last bit of hope of finding anyone alive in what is now considered the deadliest accident in the history of the garment industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAVAR, Bangladesh — The rescuers discovered her by a faint, distant sound. They had spent four days crawling through the wreckage of Rana Plaza, tons of concrete and steel pressing down, saving hundreds of people. Now only the dead remained. Except for a lone woman, a garment worker.

articles.headline: Stories of Struggle and Creativity as Sequestration Cuts Hit Home
articles.snippet: The federal budget cuts known as sequestration are being felt across the country, with some programs coping, some struggling and others closing their doors.
articles.abstract: The federal budget cuts known as sequestration are being felt across the country, with some programs coping, some struggling and others closing their doors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Facing the task of cutting 142 children from the Head Start program in Colorado Springs this fall, the teachers and administrators came up with a creative response: Have the children decorate empty chairs, then sell them for $500 apiece to stave off the worst of the across-the-board federal cuts heading their way. So far, in a month, their “Fill a Seat” fund-raiser has filled just two slots in the program.

articles.headline: Accessories No Longer Tethered to Apple
articles.snippet: Manufacturers are gravitating toward wireless connections for Apple’s products, which is helping the market for competitors’ mobile devices.
articles.abstract: Manufacturers are gravitating toward wireless connections for Apple’s products, which is helping the market for competitors’ mobile devices.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, Apple’s clout in the electronics world could be gauged by how easy it was to bump into devices tailor-made for a connection to an iPhone or iPod.
articles.byline: By Nick Wingfield and Brian X. Chen

articles.headline: Media Giants Chase Online Ads With Original Shows
articles.snippet: Major media companies, including Condé Nast, Yahoo and Hulu, are promoting online video programming on a large scale, but it is not clear whether advertising dollars will follow.
articles.abstract: Major media companies, including Condé Nast, Yahoo and Hulu, are promoting online video programming on a large scale, but it is not clear whether advertising dollars will follow.
articles.lead_paragraph: Everyone wants to be in show biz, and these days — on the Web at least — it seems as if everyone is.
articles.byline: By Leslie Kaufman and Tanzina Vega

articles.headline: A Call for New Blood on the JPMorgan Board
articles.snippet: Institutional Shareholder Services says three directors on the risk policy committee lack risk management backgrounds.
articles.abstract: Institutional Shareholder Services says three directors on the risk policy committee lack risk management backgrounds.
articles.lead_paragraph: An influential shareholder advisory firm has recommended that investors withhold their support for three JPMorgan Chase directors, citing “material failures of stewardship and risk oversight” in the wake of a big trading loss last year.
articles.byline: By Susanne Craig and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: For Media Moguls, Paydays That Stand Out
articles.snippet: Leaders in other industries may be well paid, but they earn far less than their media counterparts.
articles.abstract: Leaders in other industries may be well paid, but they earn far less than their media counterparts.
articles.lead_paragraph: What’s the difference between a media mogul and a chief executive elsewhere in the business world? About $10 million in compensation, give or take.

articles.headline: USA Network to Explore Sitcoms and Reality Shows
articles.snippet: The USA Network believes that in order to stay competitive it has to branch out into new programming directions.
articles.abstract: The USA Network believes that in order to stay competitive it has to branch out into new programming directions.
articles.lead_paragraph: For most of the past decade the USA Network has lived by the mantra “blue skies,” which has translated into programming a string of upbeat hourlong drama hits, like “Burn Notice” and “Royal Pains.”

articles.headline: Transformation of a Town Underscores Immigrants’ Impact
articles.snippet: The Westchester County community of Port Chester, N.Y., presents a microcosm of the costs and benefits that immigration reform could offer the United States.
articles.abstract: The Westchester County community of Port Chester, N.Y., presents a microcosm of the costs and benefits that immigration reform could offer the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORT CHESTER, N.Y. — Nearly 20 years after he arrived penniless in this country from Mexico, Moises owns two restaurants, with a third on the way. He has five employees, an American wife and a stepdaughter. His food even has a following on Yelp.com.

articles.headline: Jet Makers Avoid Risk by Redoing Old Models
articles.snippet: Boeing’s announcement that it had started presenting airlines with an enhanced version of its 777 jet, rather than a whole new plane, underscores the shift.
articles.abstract: Boeing’s announcement that it had started presenting airlines with an enhanced version of its 777 jet, rather than a whole new plane, underscores the shift.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a decade of pushing hard on the edge of technology, Boeing and Airbus are turning more cautious in building new jetliners.

articles.headline: Solving Equation of a Hit Film Script, With Data
articles.snippet: For as much as $20,000, Worldwide Motion Picture Group compares the story structure and genre of a script with those of released movies, looking for clues to box-office success.
articles.abstract: For as much as $20,000, Worldwide Motion Picture Group compares the story structure and genre of a script with those of released movies, looking for clues to box-office success.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Forget zombies. The data crunchers are invading Hollywood.

articles.headline: A Homemade Style of Terror: Jihadists Push New Tactics
articles.snippet: Qaeda propagandists have provided online education to teach their devotees in the United States how to carry out smaller-scale solo attacks, like the Boston bombings.
articles.abstract: Qaeda propagandists have provided online education to teach their devotees in the United States how to carry out smaller-scale solo attacks, like the Boston bombings.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Aware that intensified American counterterrorism efforts have made an ambitious Sept. 11-style plot a long shot, Al Qaeda propagandists for several years have called on their devotees in the United States to carry out smaller-scale solo attacks and provided the online education to teach them how.

articles.headline: 2 Big Banks Face Suits in Mortgage Pact Abuses
articles.snippet: Eric T. Schneiderman, New York’s top prosecutor, is poised to sue the two banks over claims they violated terms of a $26 billion national mortgage settlement.
articles.abstract: Eric T. Schneiderman, New York’s top prosecutor, is poised to sue the two banks over claims they violated terms of a $26 billion national mortgage settlement.
articles.lead_paragraph: 8:04 p.m. | Updated
